dataset.question: What does the term 'vessel' include according to COLREG Rule 3?
dataset.answer: The word 'vessel' includes every description of water craft, including non-displacement craft, WIG craft and seaplanes, used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water.
dataset.context: Rule 3(a): The word 'vessel includes every description of water craft, including non-displacement craft, WIG craft and seaplanes, used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water'.

dataset.question: What is the definition of a power-driven vessel?
dataset.answer: A power-driven vessel means any vessel propelled by machinery.
dataset.context: Rule 3(b): The term 'power-driven vessel' means any vessel propelled by machinery.

dataset.question: When is a vessel considered to be overtaking another vessel?
dataset.answer: A vessel is deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam, that is, in such a position that at night she would be able to see only the sternlight but neither of her sidelights.
dataset.context: Rule 13(b): A vessel shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam, that is, in such a position with reference to the vessel she is overtaking, that at night she would be able to see only the sternlight of that vessel but neither of her sidelights.

dataset.question: What action should two power-driven vessels take in a head-on situation?
dataset.answer: Each vessel shall alter her course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other.
dataset.context: Rule 14(a): When two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision each shall alter her course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other.

dataset.question: In a crossing situation between two power-driven vessels, which vessel must keep out of the way?
dataset.answer: The vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way and shall, if the circumstances admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel.
dataset.context: Rule 15: When two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel.

dataset.question: What does Rule 5 require regarding lookout?
dataset.answer: Every vessel shall at all times maintain a proper look-out by sight and hearing as well as by all available means appropriate in the prevailing circumstances and conditions so as to make a full appraisal of the situation and of the risk of collision.
dataset.context: Rule 5: Every vessel shall at all times maintain a proper look-out by sight and hearing as well as by all available means appropriate in the prevailing circumstances and conditions so as to make a full appraisal of the situation and of the risk of collision.

dataset.question: What factors should be considered when determining safe speed?
dataset.answer: Factors include the state of visibility, traffic density, vessel maneuverability, background light at night, weather conditions, proximity of navigational hazards, and draught in relation to available depth of water.
dataset.context: Rule 6(a): Factors include: (i) the state of visibility; (ii) the traffic density; (iii) the manoeuvrability of the vessel; (iv) at night the presence of background light; (v) the state of wind, sea and current, and the proximity of navigational hazards; (vi) the draught in relation to the available depth of water.

dataset.question: How should risk of collision be determined?
dataset.answer: Every vessel shall use all available means appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions to determine if risk of collision exists. If there is any doubt such risk shall be deemed to exist. Risk shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change.
dataset.context: Rule 7(a)(d): Every vessel shall use all available means appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions to determine if risk of collision exists. If there is any doubt such risk shall be deemed to exist. Such risk shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change.

dataset.question: What characterizes proper action to avoid collision?
dataset.answer: Any action shall be positive, made in ample time and with due regard to good seamanship. Alterations of course and/or speed shall be large enough to be readily apparent to another vessel observing visually or by radar.
dataset.context: Rule 8(a)(b): Any action to avoid collision shall be taken in accordance with the Rules and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, be positive, made in ample time and with due regard to good seamanship. Any alteration of course and/or speed shall be large enough to be readily apparent to another vessel observing visually or by radar.

dataset.question: Where should a vessel navigate in a narrow channel?
dataset.answer: A vessel proceeding along a narrow channel or fairway shall keep as near to the outer limit of the channel or fairway which lies on her starboard side as is safe and practicable.
dataset.context: Rule 9(a): A vessel proceeding along the course of a narrow channel or fairway shall keep as near to the outer limit of the channel or fairway which lies on her starboard side as is safe and practicable.

dataset.question: What is the definition of 'restricted visibility'?
dataset.answer: Restricted visibility means any condition in which visibility is restricted by fog, mist, falling snow, heavy rainstorms, sandstorms or any other similar causes.
dataset.context: Rule 3(l): The term 'restricted visibility' means any condition in which visibility is restricted by fog, mist, falling snow, heavy rainstorms, sandstorms or any other similar causes.

dataset.question: What does 'underway' mean?
dataset.answer: Underway means that a vessel is not at anchor, or made fast to the shore, or aground.
dataset.context: Rule 3(i): The word 'underway' means that a vessel is not at anchor, or made fast to the shore, or aground.

dataset.question: What is a vessel not under command?
dataset.answer: A vessel not under command means a vessel which through some exceptional circumstance is unable to maneuver as required by these Rules and is therefore unable to keep out of the way of another vessel.
dataset.context: Rule 3(f): The term 'vessel not under command' means a vessel which through some exceptional circumstance is unable to manoeuvre as required by these Rules and is therefore unable to keep out of the way of another vessel.

dataset.question: What is a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver?
dataset.answer: A vessel which from the nature of her work is restricted in her ability to maneuver as required by these Rules and therefore is unable to keep out of the way of another vessel. This includes vessels engaged in laying cables, dredging, surveying, replenishment, launching aircraft, mineclearance, or restricted towing operations.
dataset.context: Rule 3(g): The term 'vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre' means a vessel which from the nature of her work is restricted in her ability to manoeuvre as required by these Rules and therefore is unable to keep out of the way of another vessel.

dataset.question: What defines a sailing vessel according to COLREG?
dataset.answer: A sailing vessel means any vessel under sail provided that propelling machinery, if fitted, is not being used.
dataset.context: Rule 3(c): The term 'sailing vessel' means any vessel under sail provided that propelling machinery, if fitted, is not being used.

dataset.question: What must a power-driven vessel underway exhibit at night?
dataset.answer: A power-driven vessel underway shall exhibit a masthead light forward, a second masthead light abaft and higher than the forward one (vessels over 50m), sidelights, and a sternlight.
dataset.context: Rule 23(a): A power-driven vessel underway shall exhibit: (i) a masthead light forward; (ii) a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one; except that a vessel of less than 50 meters in length shall not be obliged to exhibit such light but may do so; (iii) sidelights; (iv) a sternlight.

dataset.question: What is the arc of visibility for a masthead light?
dataset.answer: A masthead light shows an unbroken light over an arc of 225 degrees, from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on either side of the vessel.
dataset.context: Rule 21(a): 'Masthead light' means a white light placed over the fore and aft centerline of the vessel showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 225 degrees and so fixed as to show the light from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on either side of the vessel.

dataset.question: What is the visibility range of a masthead light on a vessel 50 meters or more in length?
dataset.answer: A masthead light on a vessel of 50 meters or more in length shall be visible at a minimum range of 6 miles.
dataset.context: Rule 22(a): In vessels of 50 metres or more in length: - a masthead light, 6 miles.

dataset.question: What lights must a sailing vessel underway exhibit?
dataset.answer: A sailing vessel underway shall exhibit sidelights and a sternlight.
dataset.context: Rule 25(a): A sailing vessel underway shall exhibit: (i) sidelights; (ii) a sternlight.

dataset.question: What sound signal should a power-driven vessel making way through water sound in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: A power-driven vessel making way through the water shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes one prolonged blast.
dataset.context: Rule 35(a): A power-driven vessel making way through the water shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes one prolonged blast.

dataset.question: What does one short blast on the whistle mean?
dataset.answer: One short blast means 'I am altering my course to starboard'.
dataset.context: Rule 34(a): When vessels are in sight of one another, a power-driven vessel underway, when manoeuvring as authorized or required by these Rules, shall indicate that manoeuvre by the following signals on her whistle: - one short blast to mean 'I am altering my course to starboard'.

dataset.question: What does two short blasts on the whistle mean?
dataset.answer: Two short blasts mean 'I am altering my course to port'.
dataset.context: Rule 34(a): - two short blasts to mean 'I am altering my course to port'.

dataset.question: What does three short blasts on the whistle mean?
dataset.answer: Three short blasts mean 'I am operating astern propulsion'.
dataset.context: Rule 34(a): - three short blasts to mean 'I am operating astern propulsion'.

dataset.question: What signal indicates doubt or lack of understanding between vessels in sight of each other?
dataset.answer: At least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle. This may be supplemented by a light signal of at least five short and rapid flashes.
dataset.context: Rule 34(d): When vessels in sight of one another are approaching each other and from any cause either vessel fails to understand the intentions or actions of the other, or is in doubt whether sufficient action is being taken by the other to avoid collision, the vessel in doubt shall immediately indicate such doubt by giving at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle.

dataset.question: What is the responsibility hierarchy between vessels according to Rule 18?
dataset.answer: A power-driven vessel shall keep out of the way of: vessels not under command, vessels restricted in ability to maneuver, vessels engaged in fishing, and sailing vessels. A sailing vessel shall keep out of the way of vessels not under command, vessels restricted in ability to maneuver, and vessels engaged in fishing.
dataset.context: Rule 18(a)(b): A power-driven vessel underway shall keep out of the way of: (i) a vessel not under command; (ii) a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre; (iii) a vessel engaged in fishing; (iv) a sailing vessel. A sailing vessel underway shall keep out of the way of: (i) a vessel not under command; (ii) a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre; (iii) a vessel engaged in fishing.

dataset.question: What action must the give-way vessel take?
dataset.answer: Every vessel which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.
dataset.context: Rule 16: Every vessel which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

dataset.question: What must the stand-on vessel do?
dataset.answer: The stand-on vessel shall keep her course and speed. However, she may take action to avoid collision by her maneuver alone as soon as it becomes apparent that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action.
dataset.context: Rule 17(a): Where one of two vessels is to keep out of the way the other shall keep her course and speed. The latter vessel may however take action to avoid collision by her manoeuvre alone, as soon as it becomes apparent to her that the vessel required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules.

dataset.question: What is the duration of a short blast?
dataset.answer: A short blast means a blast of about one second's duration.
dataset.context: Rule 32(b): The term 'short blast' means a blast of about one second's duration.

dataset.question: What is the duration of a prolonged blast?
dataset.answer: A prolonged blast means a blast of from four to six seconds' duration.
dataset.context: Rule 32(c): The term 'prolonged blast' means a blast of from four to six seconds's duration.

dataset.question: What lights does a vessel not under command exhibit?
dataset.answer: Two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen, and when making way through the water, sidelights and a sternlight.
dataset.context: Rule 27(a): A vessel not under command shall exhibit: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen; (ii) two balls or similar shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen; (iii) when making way through the water, in addition to the lights prescribed in this paragraph, sidelights and a sternlight.

dataset.question: What lights does a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver exhibit?
dataset.answer: Three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen - the highest and lowest red, the middle white. When making way, also masthead light(s), sidelights and sternlight.
dataset.context: Rule 27(b): A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; (iii) when making way through the water, a masthead light or lights, sidelights and a sternlight in addition to the lights prescribed in subparagraph (i).

dataset.question: What lights does a vessel engaged in trawling exhibit?
dataset.answer: Two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white. When making way through the water, also sidelights and a sternlight.
dataset.context: Rule 26(b): A vessel when engaged in trawling shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white; (iii) when making way through the water, in addition to the lights prescribed in this paragraph, sidelights and a sternlight.

dataset.question: What lights does a vessel engaged in fishing (other than trawling) exhibit?
dataset.answer: Two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower white. When making way through the water, also sidelights and a sternlight.
dataset.context: Rule 26(c): A vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower white; (iii) when making way through the water, in addition to the lights prescribed in this paragraph, sidelights and a sternlight.

dataset.question: What is the minimum diameter of a ball day shape?
dataset.answer: A ball shall have a diameter of not less than 0.6 metre.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 6(a)(i): a ball shall have a diameter of not less than 0.6 metre.

dataset.question: What should a vessel do when approaching a bend in a narrow channel?
dataset.answer: A vessel nearing a bend or an area where other vessels may be obscured shall navigate with particular alertness and caution and shall sound one prolonged blast. Any approaching vessel within hearing shall answer with a prolonged blast.
dataset.context: Rule 9(f): A vessel nearing a bend or an area of a narrow channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction shall navigate with particular alertness and caution and shall sound the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34(e). Rule 34(e): Such signal shall be answered with a prolonged blast by any approaching vessel that may be within hearing around the bend.

dataset.question: What must a vessel do when crossing a traffic separation scheme?
dataset.answer: A vessel shall cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow.
dataset.context: Rule 10(c): A vessel shall so far as practicable avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so shall cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow.

dataset.question: What is the proper direction to proceed in a traffic lane?
dataset.answer: A vessel shall proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow for that lane.
dataset.context: Rule 10(b)(i): A vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow for that lane.

dataset.question: What vessels may use the inshore traffic zone?
dataset.answer: Vessels of less than 20 meters in length, sailing vessels, and vessels engaged in fishing may use the inshore traffic zone.
dataset.context: Rule 10(d)(i): A vessel shall not use an inshore traffic zone when she can safely use the appropriate traffic lane within the adjacent traffic separation scheme. However, vessels of less than 20 meters in length, sailing vessels and vessels engaged in fishing may use the inshore traffic zone.

dataset.question: What sound signal does a vessel at anchor make in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: A vessel at anchor shall at intervals of not more than one minute ring the bell rapidly for about 5 seconds. In vessels of 100 meters or more, the bell shall be sounded in the forepart and immediately after a gong in the after part.
dataset.context: Rule 35(g): A vessel at anchor shall at intervals of not more than one minute ring the bell rapidly for about 5 seconds. In a vessel of 100 metres or more in length the bell shall be sounded in the forepart of the vessel and immediately after the ringing of the bell the gong shall be sounded rapidly for about 5 seconds in the after part of the vessel.

dataset.question: What is a vessel constrained by her draught?
dataset.answer: A power-driven vessel which because of her draught in relation to the available depth and width of navigable water is severely restricted in her ability to deviate from the course she is following.
dataset.context: Rule 3(h): The term 'vessel constrained by her draught' means a power-driven vessel which because of her draught in relation to the available depth and width of navigable water, is severely restricted in her ability to deviate from the course she is following.

dataset.question: What lights does a pilot vessel on pilotage duty exhibit?
dataset.answer: Two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being white and the lower red. When underway, also sidelights and a sternlight. When at anchor, anchor lights as well.
dataset.context: Rule 29(a): A vessel engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit: (i) at or near the masthead, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being white and the lower red; (ii) when underway, in addition, sidelight and a sternlight; (iii) when at anchor, in addition to the lights prescribed in subparagraph (i), the light, lights or shape prescribed in Rule 30 for vessels at anchor.

dataset.question: What lights does a vessel at anchor exhibit?
dataset.answer: In the fore part, an all-round white light or one ball; at or near the stern at a lower level, an all-round white light. Vessels less than 50 meters may exhibit one all-round white light instead.
dataset.context: Rule 30(a): A vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen: (i) in the fore part, an all-round white light or one ball; (ii) at or near the stern and at a lower level than the light prescribed in subparagraph (i), an all-round white light. (b) A vessel of less than 50 metres in length may exhibit an all-round white light where it can best be seen instead of the lights prescribed in paragraph (a).

dataset.question: What are the colors of sidelights?
dataset.answer: The starboard sidelight is green and the port sidelight is red.
dataset.context: Rule 21(b): 'Sidelights' means a green light on the starboard side and a red light on the port side each showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 112.5 degrees.

dataset.question: What is the arc of visibility for sidelights?
dataset.answer: Sidelights show an unbroken light over an arc of 112.5 degrees, from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on their respective side.
dataset.context: Rule 21(b): 'Sidelights' means a green light on the starboard side and a red light on the port side each showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 112.5 degrees and so fixed as to show the light from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on its respective side.

dataset.question: What is the arc of visibility for a sternlight?
dataset.answer: A sternlight shows an unbroken light over an arc of 135 degrees, 67.5 degrees from right aft on each side of the vessel.
dataset.context: Rule 21(c): 'Sternlight' means a white light placed as nearly as practicable at the stern showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 135 degrees and so fixed as to show the light 67.5 degrees from right aft on each side of the vessel.

dataset.question: What additional light does a towing vessel exhibit when the tow exceeds 200 meters?
dataset.answer: Three masthead lights in a vertical line instead of one or two, and a diamond shape where it can best be seen.
dataset.context: Rule 24(a)(i)(v): A power-driven vessel when towing shall exhibit instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line. When the length of the tow, measuring from the stern of the towing vessel to the after end of the tow exceeds 200 metres, three such lights in a vertical line. (v) when the length of the tow exceeds 200 metres, a diamond shape where it can best be seen.

dataset.question: What is considered to be 'in sight of one another'?
dataset.answer: Vessels shall be deemed to be in sight of one another only when one can be observed visually from the other.
dataset.context: Rule 3(k): Vessels shall be deemed to be in sight of one another only when one can be observed visually from the other.

dataset.question: What is a vessel engaged in fishing according to COLREG?
dataset.answer: Any vessel fishing with nets, lines, trawls or other fishing apparatus which restrict maneuverability, but does not include a vessel fishing with trolling lines or other apparatus which do not restrict maneuverability.
dataset.context: Rule 3(d): The term 'vessel engaged in fishing' means any vessel fishing with nets, lines, trawls or other fishing apparatus which restrict manoeuvrability, but does not include a vessel fishing with trolling lines or other fishing apparatus which do not restrict manoeuvrability.

dataset.question: What sound signal does a power-driven vessel underway but stopped make in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: Two prolonged blasts in succession with an interval of about 2 seconds between them, at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.
dataset.context: Rule 35(b): A power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes two prolonged blasts in succession with an interval of about 2 seconds between them.

dataset.question: What sound signal does a sailing vessel make in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: At intervals of not more than 2 minutes, three blasts in succession: one prolonged followed by two short blasts.
dataset.context: Rule 35(c): A vessel not under command, a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre, a vessel constrained by her draught, a sailing vessel, a vessel engaged in fishing and a vessel engaged in towing or pushing another vessel shall, instead of the signals prescribed in paragraphs (a) or (b) sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes three blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by two short blasts.

dataset.question: When should vessels exhibit lights according to Rule 20?
dataset.answer: The lights shall be exhibited from sunset to sunrise, and during such times no other lights shall be exhibited except those that cannot be mistaken for prescribed lights. Lights may also be exhibited in restricted visibility and when deemed necessary.
dataset.context: Rule 20(b)(c): The Rules concerning lights shall be complied with from sunset to sunrise, and during such times no other lights shall be exhibited. The lights prescribed by these Rules shall, if carried, also be exhibited from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility and may be exhibited in all other circumstances when it is deemed necessary.

dataset.question: What equipment must a vessel of 100 meters or more in length carry for sound signals?
dataset.answer: A whistle, a bell, and a gong (the tone and sound of which cannot be confused with that of the bell).
dataset.context: Rule 33(a): A vessel of 100 metres or more in length shall, in addition, be provided with a gong, the tone and sound of which cannot be confused with that of the bell.

dataset.question: What action should be taken if sufficient sea room exists to avoid collision?
dataset.answer: Alteration of course alone may be the most effective action provided that it is made in good time, is substantial and does not result in another close-quarters situation.
dataset.context: Rule 8(c): If there is sufficient sea room, alteration of course alone may be the most effective action to avoid a close-quarters situation provided that it is made in good time, is substantial and does not result in another close-quarters situation.

dataset.question: When must a vessel use radar if fitted?
dataset.answer: Proper use shall be made of radar equipment if fitted and operational, including long-range scanning to obtain early warning of risk of collision and radar plotting or equivalent systematic observation.
dataset.context: Rule 7(b): Proper use shall be made of radar equipment if fitted and operational, including long-range scanning to obtain early warning of risk of collision and radar plotting or equivalent systematic observation of detected objects.

dataset.question: Can small alterations of course and speed be used to avoid collision?
dataset.answer: No, a succession of small alterations of course and/or speed should be avoided. Alterations should be large enough to be readily apparent.
dataset.context: Rule 8(b): Any alteration of course and/or speed to avoid collision shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, be large enough to be readily apparent to another vessel observing visually or by radar; a succession of small alterations of course and/or speed should be avoided.

dataset.question: What should be done to verify the effectiveness of collision avoidance action?
dataset.answer: Action taken to avoid collision shall be such as to result in passing at a safe distance. The effectiveness of the action shall be carefully checked until the other vessel is finally past and clear.
dataset.context: Rule 8(d): Action taken to avoid collision with another vessel shall be such as to result in passing at a safe distance. The effectiveness of the action shall be carefully checked until the other vessel is finally past and clear.

dataset.question: What vessels should not impede passage in a narrow channel?
dataset.answer: A vessel of less than 20 meters in length or a sailing vessel shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway.
dataset.context: Rule 9(b): A vessel of less than 20 metres in length or a sailing vessel shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway.

dataset.question: Can a vessel anchor in a narrow channel?
dataset.answer: Any vessel shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid anchoring in a narrow channel.
dataset.context: Rule 9(g): Any vessel shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid anchoring in a narrow channel.

dataset.question: How should a vessel join or leave a traffic lane?
dataset.answer: Normally join or leave at the termination of the lane, but when joining or leaving from either side shall do so at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable.
dataset.context: Rule 10(b)(iii): normally join or leave a traffic lane at the termination of the lane, but when joining or leaving from either side shall do so at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable.

dataset.question: What vessels shall not impede safe passage in a traffic lane?
dataset.answer: A vessel of less than 20 meters in length or a sailing vessel shall not impede the safe passage of a power-driven vessel following a traffic lane.
dataset.context: Rule 10(j): A vessel of less than 20 meters in length or a sailing vessel shall not impede the safe passage of a power-driven vessel following a traffic lane.

dataset.question: What are the right-of-way rules for two sailing vessels?
dataset.answer: When each has wind on a different side, the vessel with wind on the port side keeps clear. When both have wind on the same side, the windward vessel keeps clear.
dataset.context: Rule 12(a): When two sailing vessels are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision, one of them shall keep out of the way: (i) when each has the wind on a different side, the vessel which has the wind on the port side shall keep out of the way; (ii) when both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way.

dataset.question: What is the application scope of COLREG Rules?
dataset.answer: These Rules shall apply to all vessels upon the high seas and in all waters connected therewith navigable by seagoing vessels.
dataset.context: Rule 1(a): These Rules shall apply to all vessels upon the high seas and in all waters connected therewith navigable by seagoing vessels.

dataset.question: Can special rules interfere with COLREG in harbours and inland waterways?
dataset.answer: Nothing in these Rules shall interfere with the operation of special rules made by an appropriate authority for roadsteads, harbours, rivers, lakes or inland waterways. Such special rules shall conform as closely as possible to these Rules.
dataset.context: Rule 1(b): Nothing in these Rules shall interfere with the operation of special rules made by an appropriate authority for roadsteads, harbours, rivers, lakes or inland waterways connected with the high seas and navigable by seagoing vessels. Such special rules shall conform as closely as possible to these Rules.

dataset.question: What does Rule 2 state about responsibility?
dataset.answer: Nothing in these Rules shall exonerate any vessel, or the owner, master or crew thereof, from the consequences of any neglect to comply with these Rules or of the neglect of any precaution which may be required by the ordinary practice of seamen, or by the special circumstances of the case.
dataset.context: Rule 2(a): Nothing in these Rules shall exonerate any vessel, or the owner, master or crew thereof, from the consequences of any neglect to comply with these Rules or of the neglect of any precaution which may be required by the ordinary practice of seamen, or by the special circumstances of the case.

dataset.question: When can a vessel depart from COLREG Rules?
dataset.answer: In construing and complying with these Rules due regard shall be had to all dangers of navigation and collision and to any special circumstances, including the limitations of the vessels involved, which may make a departure from these Rules necessary to avoid immediate danger.
dataset.context: Rule 2(b): In construing and complying with these Rules due regard shall be had to all dangers of navigation and collision and to any special circumstances, including the limitations of the vessels involved, which may make a departure from these Rules necessary to avoid immediate danger.

dataset.question: What does the term 'seaplane' include?
dataset.answer: The word 'seaplane' includes any aircraft designed to manoeuvre on the water.
dataset.context: Rule 3(e): The word 'seaplane' includes any aircraft designed to manoeuvre on the water.

dataset.question: What does 'length' and 'breadth' mean for a vessel?
dataset.answer: The words 'length' and 'breadth' of a vessel mean her length overall and greatest breadth.
dataset.context: Rule 3(j): The words 'length' and 'breadth' of a vessel mean her length overall and greatest breadth.

dataset.question: What is a Wing-In-Ground (WIG) craft?
dataset.answer: A multimodal craft which, in its main operational mode, flies in close proximity to the surface by utilizing surface-effect action.
dataset.context: Rule 3(m): The term 'Wing-In-Ground (WIG) craft' means a multimodal craft which, in its main operational mode, flies in close proximity to the surface by utilizing surface-effect action.

dataset.question: To which vessels does Section I of Part B apply?
dataset.answer: Rules in this Section apply in any condition of visibility.
dataset.context: Rule 4: Rules in this Section apply in any condition of visibility.

dataset.question: What additional factors should vessels with operational radar consider for safe speed?
dataset.answer: The characteristics, efficiency and limitations of the radar equipment; any constraints imposed by the radar range scale in use; the effect on radar detection of the sea state, weather and other sources of interference; the possibility that small vessels, ice and other floating objects may not be detected by radar at an adequate range; the number, location and movement of vessels detected by radar; and the more exact assessment of visibility possible when radar is used.
dataset.context: Rule 6(b): Additionally, by vessels with operational radar: (i) the characteristics, efficiency and limitations of the radar equipment; (ii) any constraints imposed by the radar range scale in use; (iii) the effect on radar detection of the sea state, weather and other sources of interference; (iv) the possibility that small vessels, ice and other floating objects may not be detected by radar at an adequate range; (v) the number, location and movement of vessels detected by radar; (vi) the more exact assessment of the visibility that may be possible when radar is used to determine the range of vessels or other objects in the vicinity.

dataset.question: Should assumptions be made based on scanty radar information?
dataset.answer: Assumptions shall not be made on the basis of scanty information, especially scanty radar information.
dataset.context: Rule 7(c): Assumptions shall not be made on the basis of scanty information, especially scanty radar information.

dataset.question: When may risk of collision exist even with appreciable bearing change?
dataset.answer: Such risk may sometimes exist even when an appreciable bearing change is evident, particularly when approaching a very large vessel or a tow or when approaching a vessel at close range.
dataset.context: Rule 7(d)(ii): such risk may sometimes exist even when an appreciable bearing change is evident, particularly when approaching a very large vessel or a tow or when approaching a vessel at close range.

dataset.question: What should a vessel do if necessary to avoid collision or assess the situation?
dataset.answer: If necessary to avoid collision or allow more time to assess the situation, a vessel shall slacken her speed or take all way off by stopping or reversing her means of propulsion.
dataset.context: Rule 8(e): If necessary to avoid collision or allow more to assess the situation, a vessel shall slacken her speed or take all way off by stopping or reversing her means of propulsion.

dataset.question: What are the obligations of a vessel required not to impede passage?
dataset.answer: A vessel which, by any of these Rules, is required not to impede the passage or safe passage of another vessel shall, when required by the circumstances of the case, take early action to allow sufficient sea room for the safe passage of the other vessel.
dataset.context: Rule 8(f)(i): A vessel which, by any of these Rules, is required not to impede the passage or safe passage of another vessel shall, when required by the circumstances of the case, take early action to allow sufficient sea room for the safe passage of the other vessel.

dataset.question: Is a vessel whose passage is not to be impeded relieved of obligations?
dataset.answer: A vessel the passage of which is not to be impeded remains fully obliged to comply with the rules of this part when the two vessels are approaching one another so as to involve risk of collision.
dataset.context: Rule 8(f)(iii): A vessel the passage of which is not to be impeded remains fully obliged to comply with the rules of this part when the two vessels are approaching one another so as to involve risk of collision.

dataset.question: Can a vessel engaged in fishing impede passage in a narrow channel?
dataset.answer: A vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any other vessel navigating within a narrow channel or fairway.
dataset.context: Rule 9(c): A vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any other vessel navigating within a narrow channel or fairway.

dataset.question: What should vessels do when crossing a narrow channel?
dataset.answer: A vessel shall not cross a narrow channel or fairway if such crossing impedes the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within such channel or fairway.
dataset.context: Rule 9(d): A vessel shall not cross a narrow channel or fairway if such crossing impedes the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within such channel or fairway. The latter vessel may use the sound signal prescribed in Rule 34(d) if in doubt as to the intention of the crossing vessel.

dataset.question: What signals are used for overtaking in a narrow channel?
dataset.answer: The vessel intending to overtake shall indicate her intention by sounding two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast to mean 'I intend to overtake you on your starboard side' or two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts to mean 'I intend to overtake you on your port side'. The vessel to be overtaken shall, if in agreement, sound one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast.
dataset.context: Rule 9(e)(i) and Rule 34(c): In a narrow channel or fairway when overtaking can take place only if the vessel to be overtaken has to take action to permit safe passing, the vessel intending to overtake shall indicate her intention by sounding the appropriate signal. The vessel to be overtaken shall, if in agreement, sound the appropriate signal and take steps to permit safe passing.

dataset.question: Does Rule 10 relieve any vessel of obligations under other rules?
dataset.answer: This Rule applies to traffic separation schemes adopted by the Organization and does not relieve any vessel of her obligation under any other rule.
dataset.context: Rule 10(a): This Rule Applies to traffic separation schemes adopted by the Organization and does not relieve any vessel of her obligation under any other rule.

dataset.question: How should vessels keep clear of traffic separation lines?
dataset.answer: A vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall so far as practicable keep clear of a traffic separation line or separation zone.
dataset.context: Rule 10(b)(ii): so far as practicable keep clear of a traffic separation line or separation zone.

dataset.question: When may a vessel use an inshore traffic zone?
dataset.answer: A vessel shall not use an inshore traffic zone when she can safely use the appropriate traffic lane. However, vessels of less than 20 meters in length, sailing vessels and vessels engaged in fishing may use the inshore traffic zone. A vessel may also use it when en route to or from a port, offshore installation, pilot station or any other place within the zone, or to avoid immediate danger.
dataset.context: Rule 10(d): A vessel shall not use an inshore traffic zone when she can safely use the appropriate traffic lane within the adjacent traffic separation scheme. However, vessels of less than 20 meters in length, sailing vessels and vessels engaged in fishing may use the inshore traffic zone. Notwithstanding subparagraph (d)(i), a vessel may use an inshore traffic zone when en route to or from a port, offshore installation or structure, pilot station or any other place situated within the inshore traffic zone, or to avoid immediate danger.

dataset.question: When may a vessel enter a separation zone?
dataset.answer: A vessel, other than a crossing vessel or a vessel joining or leaving a lane, shall not normally enter a separation zone or cross a separation line except in cases of emergency to avoid immediate danger or to engage in fishing within a separation zone.
dataset.context: Rule 10(e): A vessel, other than a crossing vessel, or a vessel joining or leaving a lane shall not normally enter a separation zone or cross a separation line except: (i) in cases of emergency to avoid immediate danger; (ii) to engage in fishing within a separation zone.

dataset.question: Should vessels avoid anchoring in traffic separation schemes?
dataset.answer: A vessel shall so far as practicable avoid anchoring in a traffic separation scheme or in areas near its terminations.
dataset.context: Rule 10(g): A vessel shall so far as practicable avoid anchoring in a traffic separation scheme or in areas near its terminations.

dataset.question: Can a vessel engaged in fishing impede vessels in traffic lanes?
dataset.answer: A vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any vessel following a traffic lane.
dataset.context: Rule 10(i): A vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any vessel following a traffic lane.

dataset.question: Are vessels restricted in ability to maneuver exempt in traffic separation schemes?
dataset.answer: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when engaged in an operation for the maintenance of safety of navigation in a traffic separation scheme is exempted from complying with this Rule to the extent necessary to carry out the operation.
dataset.context: Rule 10(k): A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when engaged in an operation for the maintenance of safety of navigation in a traffic separation scheme is exempted from complying with this Rule to the extent necessary to carry out the operation.

dataset.question: What about vessels laying submarine cables in traffic schemes?
dataset.answer: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when engaged in an operation for the laying, servicing or picking up of a submarine cable, within a traffic separation scheme, is exempted from complying with this Rule to the extent necessary to carry out the operation.
dataset.context: Rule 10(l): A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when engaged in an operation for the laying, servicing or picking up of a submarine cable, within a traffic separation scheme, is exempted from complying with this Rule to the extent necessary to carry out the operation.

dataset.question: To which vessels does Section II of Part B apply?
dataset.answer: Rules in this Section apply to vessels in sight of one another.
dataset.context: Rule 11: Rules in this Section apply to vessels in sight of one another.

dataset.question: What should a sailing vessel do if uncertain about another vessel's wind side?
dataset.answer: If a vessel with the wind on the port side sees a vessel to windward and cannot determine with certainty whether the other vessel has the wind on the port or on the starboard side, she shall keep out of the way of the other.
dataset.context: Rule 12(a)(iii): if a vessel with the wind on the port side sees a vessel to windward and cannot determine with certainty whether the other vessel has the wind on the port or on the starboard side, she shall keep out of the way of the other.

dataset.question: How is the windward side determined for sailing vessels?
dataset.answer: For the purposes of this Rule the windward side shall be deemed to be the side opposite to that on which the mainsail is carried or, in the case of a square-rigged vessel, the side opposite to that on which the largest fore-and-aft sail is carried.
dataset.context: Rule 12(b): For the purposes of this Rule the windward side shall be deemed to be the side opposite to that on which the mainsail is carried or, in the case of a square-rigged vessel, the side opposite to that on which the largest fore-and-aft sail is carried.

dataset.question: Does the overtaking rule apply to all sections of Part B?
dataset.answer: Notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of Part B, Sections I and II any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken.
dataset.context: Rule 13(a): Notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of Part B, Sections I and II any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken.

dataset.question: What should a vessel assume if in doubt about overtaking?
dataset.answer: When a vessel is in any doubt as to whether she is overtaking another, she shall assume that this is the case and act accordingly.
dataset.context: Rule 13(c): When a vessel is in any doubt as to whether she is overtaking another, she shall assume that this is the case and act accordingly.

dataset.question: Does subsequent bearing change relieve an overtaking vessel?
dataset.answer: Any subsequent alteration of the bearing between the two vessels shall not make the overtaking vessel a crossing vessel within the meaning of these Rules or relieve her of the duty of keeping clear of the overtaken vessel until she is finally past and clear.
dataset.context: Rule 13(d): Any subsequent alteration of the bearing between the two vessels shall not make the overtaking vessel a crossing vessel within the meaning of these Rules or relieve her of the duty of keeping clear of the overtaken vessel until she is finally past and clear.

dataset.question: How can a head-on situation be recognized at night?
dataset.answer: Such a situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel sees the other ahead or nearly ahead and by night she could see the masthead lights of the other in a line or nearly in a line and/or both sidelights.
dataset.context: Rule 14(b): Such a situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel sees the other ahead or nearly ahead and by night she could see the masthead lights of the other in a line or nearly in a line and/or both sidelights and by day she observes the corresponding aspect of the other vessel.

dataset.question: What should a vessel assume if in doubt about a head-on situation?
dataset.answer: When a vessel is in any doubt as to whether such a situation exists she shall assume that it does exist and act accordingly.
dataset.context: Rule 14(c): When a vessel is in any doubt as to whether such a situation exists she shall assume that it does exist and act accordingly.

dataset.question: When may the stand-on vessel take action?
dataset.answer: The stand-on vessel may however take action to avoid collision by her manoeuvre alone, as soon as it becomes apparent to her that the vessel required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules.
dataset.context: Rule 17(a)(ii): The latter vessel may however take action to avoid collision by her manoeuvre alone, as soon as it becomes apparent to her that the vessel required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules.

dataset.question: When must the stand-on vessel take action?
dataset.answer: When, from any cause, the vessel required to keep her course and speed finds herself so close that collision cannot be avoided by the action of the give-way vessel alone, she shall take such action as will best aid to avoid collision.
dataset.context: Rule 17(b): When, from any cause, the vessel required to keep her course and speed finds herself so close that collision cannot be avoided by the action of the give-way vessel alone, she shall take such action as will best aid to avoid collision.

dataset.question: What course alteration should a power-driven vessel avoid in crossing situations?
dataset.answer: A power-driven vessel which takes action in a crossing situation to avoid collision with another power-driven vessel shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, not alter course to port for a vessel on her own port side.
dataset.context: Rule 17(c): A power-driven vessel which takes action in a crossing situation in accordance with sub-paragraph (a)(ii) of this Rule to avoid collision with another power-driven vessel shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, not alter course to port for a vessel on her own port side.

dataset.question: Is the give-way vessel relieved of obligations by the stand-on vessel's actions?
dataset.answer: This Rule does not relieve the give-way vessel of her obligation to keep out of the way.
dataset.context: Rule 17(d): This Rule does not relieve the give-way vessel of her obligation to keep out of the way.

dataset.question: What vessels must a vessel engaged in fishing keep clear of?
dataset.answer: A vessel engaged in fishing when underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel not under command and a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre.
dataset.context: Rule 18(c): A vessel engaged in fishing when underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of: (i) a vessel not under command; (ii) a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre.

dataset.question: What must vessels do regarding vessels constrained by draught?
dataset.answer: Any vessel other than a vessel not under command or a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draught, exhibiting the signals in Rule 28.
dataset.context: Rule 18(d)(i): Any vessel other than a vessel not under command or a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draught, exhibiting the signals in Rule 28.

dataset.question: How should a vessel constrained by draught navigate?
dataset.answer: A vessel constrained by her draught shall navigate with particular caution having full regard to her special condition.
dataset.context: Rule 18(d)(ii): A vessel constrained by her draught shall navigate with particular caution having full regard to her special condition.

dataset.question: How should seaplanes behave on water?
dataset.answer: A seaplane on the water shall, in general, keep well clear of all vessels and avoid impeding their navigation. In circumstances, however, where risk of collision exists, she shall comply with the Rules of this Part.
dataset.context: Rule 18(e): A seaplane on the water shall, in general, keep well clear of all vessels and avoid impeding their navigation. In circumstances, however, where risk of collision exists, she shall comply with the Rules of this Part.

dataset.question: How should WIG craft behave when taking off or landing?
dataset.answer: A WIG craft shall, when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface, keep well clear of all other vessels and avoid impeding their navigation.
dataset.context: Rule 18(f)(i): A WIG craft shall, when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface, keep well clear of all other vessels and avoid impeding their navigation.

dataset.question: How does a WIG craft comply with rules when on the water?
dataset.answer: A WIG craft operating on the water surface shall comply with the Rules of this Part as a power-driven vessel.
dataset.context: Rule 18(f)(ii): a WIG craft operating on the water surface shall comply with the Rules of this Part as a power-driven vessel.

dataset.question: To which vessels does Rule 19 apply?
dataset.answer: This Rule applies to vessels not in sight of one another when navigating in or near an area of restricted visibility.
dataset.context: Rule 19(a): This Rule applies to vessels not in sight of one another when navigating in or near an area of restricted visibility.

dataset.question: What should power-driven vessels do in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: Every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility. A power-driven vessel shall have engines ready for immediate manoeuvre.
dataset.context: Rule 19(b): Every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility. A power-driven vessel shall have engines ready for immediate manoeuvre.

dataset.question: What course alterations should be avoided when detected by radar in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: When such action consists of an alteration of course, so far as possible the following shall be avoided: an alteration of course to port for a vessel forward of the beam, other than for a vessel being overtaken; an alteration of course towards a vessel abeam or abaft the beam.
dataset.context: Rule 19(d): A vessel which detects by radar alone the presence of another vessel shall determine if a close-quarters situation is developing and/or risk of collision exists. If so, she shall take avoiding action in ample time, provided that when such action consists of an alteration of course, so far as possible the following shall be avoided: (i) an alteration of course to port for a vessel forward of the beam, other than for a vessel being overtaken; (ii) an alteration of course towards a vessel abeam or abaft the beam.

dataset.question: What should a vessel do when hearing a fog signal forward of the beam?
dataset.answer: Every vessel which hears apparently forward of her beam the fog signal of another vessel, or which cannot avoid a close quarters situation with another vessel forward of her beam, shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course. She shall if necessary take all her way off and in any event navigate with extreme caution until danger of collision is over.
dataset.context: Rule 19(e): Except where it has been determined that a risk of collision does not exist, every vessel which hears apparently forward of her beam the fog signal of another vessel, or which cannot avoid a close quarters situation with another vessel forward of her beam, shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course. She shall if necessary take all her way off and in any event navigate with extreme caution until danger of collision is over.

dataset.question: In what conditions must lights be exhibited?
dataset.answer: The Rules concerning lights shall be complied with from sunset to sunrise, and during such times no other lights shall be exhibited, except such lights as cannot be mistaken for the lights specified in these Rules or do not impair their visibility or distinctive character.
dataset.context: Rule 20(b): The Rules concerning lights shall be complied with from sunset to sunrise, and during such times no other lights shall be exhibited, except such lights as cannot be mistaken for the lights specified in these Rules or do not impair their visibility or distinctive character, or interfere with the keeping of a proper look-out.

dataset.question: When may prescribed lights be exhibited during daytime?
dataset.answer: The lights prescribed by these Rules shall, if carried, also be exhibited from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility and may be exhibited in all other circumstances when it is deemed necessary.
dataset.context: Rule 20(c): The lights prescribed by these Rules shall, if carried, also be exhibited from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility and may be exhibited in all other circumstances when it is deemed necessary.

dataset.question: When must shapes be displayed?
dataset.answer: The Rules concerning shapes shall be complied with by day.
dataset.context: Rule 20(d): The Rules concerning shapes shall be complied with by day.

dataset.question: What is a towing light?
dataset.answer: A towing light means a yellow light having the same characteristics as the sternlight.
dataset.context: Rule 21(d): 'Towing light' means a yellow light having the same characteristics as the 'sternlight' defined in paragraph(c) of this Rule.

dataset.question: What is an all-round light?
dataset.answer: An all-round light means a light showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 360 degrees.
dataset.context: Rule 21(e): 'All round light' means a light showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 360 degrees.

dataset.question: What is a flashing light?
dataset.answer: A flashing light means a light flashing at regular intervals at a frequency of 120 flashes or more per minute.
dataset.context: Rule 21(f): 'Flashing light' means a light flashing at regular intervals at a frequency of 120 flashes or more per minute.

dataset.question: What is the visibility range of a sidelight on a vessel 50 meters or more in length?
dataset.answer: A sidelight on a vessel of 50 meters or more in length shall be visible at a minimum range of 3 miles.
dataset.context: Rule 22(a): In vessels of 50 metres or more in length: - a sidelight, 3 miles.

dataset.question: What is the visibility range of a sternlight on vessels 12-50 meters in length?
dataset.answer: A sternlight on a vessel of 12 metres or more but less than 50 metres in length shall be visible at a minimum range of 2 miles.
dataset.context: Rule 22(b): In vessels of 12 metres or more in length but less than 50 m in length: - a sternlight, 2 miles.

dataset.question: What additional light does an air-cushion vessel exhibit?
dataset.answer: An air-cushion vessel when operating in the non-displacement mode shall, in addition to the lights prescribed for power-driven vessels, exhibit an all-round flashing yellow light.
dataset.context: Rule 23(b): An air-cushion vessel when operating in the non-displacement mode shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule exhibit an all-round flashing yellow light.

dataset.question: What additional light does a WIG craft exhibit when taking off?
dataset.answer: A WIG craft only when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface shall, in addition to the lights prescribed for power-driven vessels, exhibit a high intensity all-round flashing red light.
dataset.context: Rule 23(c): A WIG craft only when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule, exhibit a high intensity all-round flashing red light.

dataset.question: What lights may a power-driven vessel less than 12 meters exhibit?
dataset.answer: A power-driven vessel of less than 12 meters in length may in lieu of the lights prescribed for larger vessels exhibit an all-round white light and sidelights.
dataset.context: Rule 23(d)(i): A power-driven vessel of less than 12 meters in length may in lieu of the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule exhibit an all-round white light and sidelights.

dataset.question: What lights does a composite towing unit exhibit?
dataset.answer: When a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 23.
dataset.context: Rule 24(b): When a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 23.

dataset.question: What lights does a power-driven vessel pushing or towing alongside exhibit?
dataset.answer: A power-driven vessel when pushing ahead or towing alongside shall exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line, sidelights, and a sternlight.
dataset.context: Rule 24(c): A power-driven vessel when pushing ahead or towing alongside, except in the case of a composite unit, shall exhibit: (i) instead of the light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (a)(ii), two masthead lights in a vertical line; (ii) sidelights; (iii) a sternlight.

dataset.question: What lights does a vessel or object being towed exhibit?
dataset.answer: A vessel or object being towed shall exhibit sidelights, a sternlight, and when the length of the tow exceeds 200 metres, a diamond shape where it can best be seen.
dataset.context: Rule 24(e): A vessel or object being towed, other than those mentioned in paragraph (g) of this Rule, shall exhibit: (i) sidelights; (ii) a sternlight; (iii) when the length of the tow exceeds 200 metres, a diamond shape where it can best be seen.

dataset.question: What lights does an inconspicuous partly submerged tow less than 25 meters wide exhibit?
dataset.answer: If it is less than 25 metres in breadth, one all-round white light at or near the forward end and one at or near the after end except that dracones need not exhibit a light at or near the forward end.
dataset.context: Rule 24(g)(i): if it is less than 25 metres in breadth, one all-round white light at or near the forward end and one at or near the after end except that dracones need not exhibit a light at or near the forward end.

dataset.question: What if a towed vessel cannot exhibit prescribed lights?
dataset.answer: Where from any sufficient cause it is impracticable for a vessel or object being towed to exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed, all possible measures shall be taken to light the vessel or object towed or at least to indicate the presence of such vessel or object.
dataset.context: Rule 24(h): Where from any sufficient cause it is impracticable for a vessel or object being towed to exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in paragraph (e) or (g) of this Rule, all possible measures shall be taken to light the vessel or object towed or at least to indicate the presence of such vessel or object.

dataset.question: When is a towing vessel not required to exhibit towing lights?
dataset.answer: Where from any sufficient cause it is impracticable for a vessel not normally engaged in towing operations to display the prescribed towing lights, such vessel shall not be required to exhibit those lights when engaged in towing another vessel in distress or otherwise in need of assistance. All possible measures shall be taken to indicate the nature of the relationship between the vessels.
dataset.context: Rule 24(i): Where from any sufficient cause it is impracticable for a vessel not normally engaged in towing operations to display the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) or (c) of this Rule, such vessel shall not be required to exhibit those lights when engaged in towing another vessel in distress or otherwise in need of assistance.

dataset.question: What optional lights may a sailing vessel under 20 meters exhibit?
dataset.answer: In a sailing vessel of less than 20 metres in length the sidelights and sternlight may be combined in one lantern carried at or near the top of the mast where it can best be seen.
dataset.context: Rule 25(b): In a sailing vessel of less than 20 metres in length the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule may be combined in one lantern carried at or near the top of the mast where it can best be seen.

dataset.question: What additional optional lights may sailing vessels exhibit?
dataset.answer: A sailing vessel underway may, in addition to prescribed lights, exhibit at or near the top of the mast two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower green, but these shall not be exhibited with the combined lantern.
dataset.context: Rule 25(c): A sailing vessel underway may, in addition to the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule, exhibit at or near the top of the mast, where they can best be seen, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower green, but these lights shall not be exhibited in conjunction with the combined lantern permitted by paragraph (b) of this Rule.

dataset.question: What lights must sailing vessels under 7 meters carry?
dataset.answer: A sailing vessel of less than 7 metres in length shall, if practicable, exhibit the prescribed lights, but if she does not, she shall have ready at hand an electric torch or lighted lantern showing a white light which shall be exhibited in sufficient time to prevent collision.
dataset.context: Rule 25(d)(i): A sailing vessel of less than 7 metres in length shall, if practicable, exhibit the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) or (b) of this Rule, but if she does not, she shall have ready at hand an electric torch or lighted lantern showing a white light which shall be exhibited in sufficient time to prevent collision.

dataset.question: What shape does a sailing vessel under power exhibit?
dataset.answer: A vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery shall exhibit forward where it can best be seen a conical shape, apex downwards.
dataset.context: Rule 25(e): A vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery shall exhibit forward where it can best be seen a conical shape, apex down wards.

dataset.question: What lights and shapes do trawling vessels exhibit?
dataset.answer: A vessel when engaged in trawling shall exhibit two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white, or a shape consisting of two cones with their apexes together. When making way, also sidelights and a sternlight.
dataset.context: Rule 26(b): A vessel when engaged in trawling shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white, or a shape consisting of two cones with their apexes together in a vertical line one above the other; (iii) when making way through the water, in addition to the lights prescribed in this paragraph, sidelights and a sternlight.

dataset.question: What additional light does a fishing vessel with outlying gear exhibit?
dataset.answer: When there is outlying gear extending more than 150 metres horizontally from the vessel, an all-round white light or a cone apex upwards in the direction of the gear.
dataset.context: Rule 26(c)(ii): when there is outlying gear extending more than 150 metres horizontally from the vessel, an all-round white light or a cone apex upwards in the direction of the gear.

dataset.question: Must a vessel not engaged in fishing remove fishing lights?
dataset.answer: A vessel when not engaged in fishing shall not exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in this Rule, but only those prescribed for a vessel of her length.
dataset.context: Rule 26(e): A vessel when not engaged in fishing shall not exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in this Rule, but only those prescribed for a vessel of her length.

dataset.question: What day shapes does a vessel not under command exhibit?
dataset.answer: Two balls or similar shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen.
dataset.context: Rule 27(a)(ii): two balls or similar shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen.

dataset.question: What day shapes does a vessel restricted in ability to maneuver exhibit?
dataset.answer: Three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond.
dataset.context: Rule 27(b)(ii): three shapes in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these shapes shall be balls and the middle one a diamond.

dataset.question: What lights does a severely restricted towing vessel exhibit?
dataset.answer: A power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow shall, in addition to towing lights, exhibit the lights or shapes for vessels restricted in ability to maneuver.
dataset.context: Rule 27(c): A power-driven vessel engaged in a towing operation such as severely restricts the towing vessel and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course shall, in addition to the lights or shapes prescribed in Rule 24(a), exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in sub-paragraphs (b)(i) and (ii) of this Rule.

dataset.question: What lights indicate the obstructed side of a dredging vessel?
dataset.answer: Two all-round red lights or two balls in a vertical line indicate the side on which the obstruction exists.
dataset.context: Rule 27(d)(i): two all-round red lights or two balls in a vertical line to indicate the side on which the obstruction exists.

dataset.question: What lights indicate the safe passing side of a dredging vessel?
dataset.answer: Two all-round green lights or two diamonds in a vertical line indicate the side on which another vessel may pass.
dataset.context: Rule 27(d)(ii): two all-round green lights or two diamonds in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass.

dataset.question: What do diving operations vessels less than 12 meters exhibit?
dataset.answer: Whenever the size makes it impracticable to exhibit all prescribed lights and shapes, diving vessels shall exhibit three all-round lights in a vertical line (highest and lowest red, middle white) and a rigid replica of International Code flag 'A' not less than 1 metre in height.
dataset.context: Rule 27(e): Whenever the size of a vessel engaged in diving operations makes it impracticable to exhibit all lights and shapes prescribed in paragraph (d) of this Rule, the following shall be exhibited: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; (ii) a rigid replica of the International Code flag 'A' not less than 1 metre in height.

dataset.question: What lights do mineclearance vessels exhibit?
dataset.answer: A vessel engaged in mineclearance operations shall exhibit three all-round green lights or three balls. One near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These indicate it is dangerous to approach within 1000 metres.
dataset.context: Rule 27(f): A vessel engaged in mineclearance operations shall in addition to the lights prescribed for a power-driven vessel or to the lights or shape prescribed for a vessel at anchor, exhibit three all-round green lights or three balls. One of these lights or shapes shall be exhibited near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. These lights or shapes indicate that it is dangerous for another vessel to approach within 1000 metres of the mineclearance vessel.

dataset.question: Are small vessels exempt from Rule 27 requirements?
dataset.answer: Vessels of less than 12 metres in length, except those engaged in diving operations, shall not be required to exhibit the lights and shapes prescribed in this Rule.
dataset.context: Rule 27(g): Vessels of less than 12 metres in length, except those engaged in diving operations, shall not be required to exhibit the lights and shapes prescribed in this Rule.

dataset.question: Are Rule 27 signals distress signals?
dataset.answer: The signals prescribed in this Rule are not signals of vessels in distress and requiring assistance. Such signals are contained in Annex IV to these Regulations.
dataset.context: Rule 27(h): The signals prescribed in this Rule are not signals of vessels in distress and requiring assistance. Such signals are contained in Annex IV to these Regulations.

dataset.question: Can NUC lights be used as part of RAM lights?
dataset.answer: Not under command all-round red lights may be used as part of the Restricted Ability to Manoeuvre lights provided vertical and horizontal distances required by COLREG are complied with and the electrical system allows the all-round white light to be switched on independently from the two red lights.
dataset.context: MSC.1/Circ.1260 - Rule 27(b)(i): 'Not under command' (NUC) all-round red lights (Rule 27(a)(ii)) may be used as part of the 'Restricted Ability to Manoeuvre' (RAM) lights provided the vertical and horizontal distances required by COLREG 1972 are complied with and the electrical system is arranged so that the all-round white light (RAM) may be switched on independently from the two all-round red lights (NUC).

dataset.question: What lights and shapes does a vessel constrained by draught exhibit?
dataset.answer: A vessel constrained by her draught may, in addition to power-driven vessel lights, exhibit where they can best be seen three all-round red lights in a vertical line, or a cylinder.
dataset.context: Rule 28: A vessel constrained by her draught may, in addition to the lights prescribed for power-driven vessels in rule 23, exhibit where they can best be seen three all-round red lights in a vertical line, or a cylinder.

dataset.question: What lights does a pilot vessel not on duty exhibit?
dataset.answer: A pilot vessel when not engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed for a similar vessel of her length.
dataset.context: Rule 29(b): A pilot vessel when not engaged on pilotage duty shall exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed for a similar vessel of her length.

dataset.question: May vessels at anchor use working lights?
dataset.answer: A vessel at anchor may, and a vessel of 100 metres and more in length shall, also use the available working or equivalent lights to illuminate her decks.
dataset.context: Rule 30(c): A vessel at anchor may, and a vessel of 100 metres and more in length shall, also use the available working or equivalent lights to illuminate her decks.

dataset.question: What additional lights and shapes does a vessel aground exhibit?
dataset.answer: A vessel aground shall exhibit the anchor lights and in addition, where they can best be seen, two all-round red lights in a vertical line and three balls in a vertical line.
dataset.context: Rule 30(d): A vessel aground shall exhibit the lights prescribed in paragraph (a) or (b) of this Rule and in addition, where they can best be seen: (i) two all-round red lights in a vertical line; (ii) three balls in a vertical line.

dataset.question: Are small vessels at anchor exempt from anchor light requirements?
dataset.answer: A vessel of less than 7 metres in length, when at anchor, not in or near a narrow channel, fairway or anchorage, or where other vessels normally navigate, shall not be required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes.
dataset.context: Rule 30(e): A vessel of less than 7 metres in length, when at anchor, not in or near a narrow channel, fairway or anchorage, or where other vessels normally navigate, shall not be required to exhibit the lights or shape prescribed in paragraphs (a), (b) of this Rule.

dataset.question: Are small vessels aground exempt from aground signals?
dataset.answer: A vessel of less than 12 metres in length, when aground, shall not be required to exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed for aground vessels.
dataset.context: Rule 30(f): A vessel of less than 12 metres in length, when aground, shall not be required to exhibit the lights or shapes prescribed in sub-paragraphs (d)(i) and (ii) of this Rule.

dataset.question: When can seaplanes and WIG craft exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar as possible?
dataset.answer: Where it is impracticable for a seaplane or a WIG craft to exhibit lights and shapes of the characteristics or in the positions prescribed in the Rules, she shall exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar in characteristics and position as is possible.
dataset.context: Rule 31: Where it is impracticable for a seaplane or a WIG craft to exhibit lights and shapes of the characteristics or in the positions prescribed in the Rules of this Part she shall exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar in characteristics and position as is possible.

dataset.question: What is a whistle according to COLREG?
dataset.answer: The word 'whistle' means any sound signalling appliance capable of producing the prescribed blasts and which complies with the specifications in Annex III.
dataset.context: Rule 32(a): The word 'whistle' means any sound signalling appliance capable of producing the prescribed blasts and which complies with the specifications in Annex III to these Regulations.

dataset.question: What sound equipment must a vessel of 20 meters or more carry?
dataset.answer: A vessel of 20 metres or more in length shall be provided with a bell in addition to a whistle.
dataset.context: Rule 33(a): A vessel of 20 metres or more in length shall be provided with a bell in addition to a whistle.

dataset.question: May the bell and gong be replaced by other equipment?
dataset.answer: The bell or gong or both may be replaced by other equipment having the same respective sound characteristics, provided that manual sounding of the required signals shall always be possible.
dataset.context: Rule 33(a): The bell or gong or both may be replaced by other equipment having the same respective sound characteristics, provided that manual sounding of the required signals shall always be possible.

dataset.question: What must vessels under 12 meters carry for sound signals?
dataset.answer: A vessel of less than 12 metres in length shall not be obliged to carry the prescribed sound signalling appliances but if she does not, she shall be provided with some other means of making an efficient sound signal.
dataset.context: Rule 33(b): A vessel of less than 12 metres in length shall not be obliged to carry the sound signalling appliances prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule but if she does not, she shall be provided with some other means of making an efficient sound signal.

dataset.question: May whistle signals be supplemented by light signals?
dataset.answer: Any vessel may supplement the whistle signals by light signals, repeated as appropriate, whilst the manoeuvre is being carried out. These light signals shall have specified meanings: one flash for starboard, two flashes for port, three flashes for astern propulsion.
dataset.context: Rule 34(b): Any vessel may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in paragraph (a) of this Rule by light signals, repeated as appropriate, whilst the manoeuvre is being carried out.

dataset.question: What are the characteristics of maneuvering light signals?
