dataset.answer: The duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less than ten seconds. The light shall be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles.
dataset.context: Rule 34(b)(ii)(iii): the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less than ten seconds; the light used for this signals shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles.

dataset.question: What signal indicates agreement to be overtaken in a narrow channel?
dataset.answer: One prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast, in that order.
dataset.context: Rule 34(c)(ii): the vessel about to be overtaken when acting in accordance with Rule 9(e)(i) shall indicate her agreement by the following signal on her whistle: one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast, in that order.

dataset.question: What sound signal should vessels use when nearing a blind bend?
dataset.answer: A vessel nearing a bend or an area where other vessels may be obscured shall sound one prolonged blast. Such signal shall be answered with a prolonged blast by any approaching vessel within hearing.
dataset.context: Rule 34(e): A vessel nearing a bend or an area of a channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction shall sound one prolonged blast. Such signal shall be answered with a prolonged blast by any approaching vessel that may be within hearing around the bend.

dataset.question: If multiple whistles are fitted far apart, which should be used?
dataset.answer: If whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 metres, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
dataset.context: Rule 34(f): If whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 metres, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

dataset.question: What sound signal does a vessel towed make in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: A vessel towed or if more than one vessel is towed the last vessel of the tow, if manned, shall sound four blasts in succession (one prolonged followed by three short blasts) at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.
dataset.context: Rule 35(e): A vessel towed or if more than one vessel is towed the last vessel of the tow, if manned, shall at intervals of not more than 2 minutes sound four blasts in succession, namely one prolonged followed by three short blasts.

dataset.question: What sound signal does a composite pushing unit make in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: When a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and shall give the signals for power-driven vessels.
dataset.context: Rule 35(f): When a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit they shall be regarded as a power-driven vessel and shall give the signals prescribed in paragraphs (a) or (b) of this Rule.

dataset.question: What additional sound signal may a vessel at anchor make?
dataset.answer: A vessel at anchor may in addition sound three blasts in succession, namely one short, one prolonged and one short blast, to give warning of her position and of the possibility of collision to an approaching vessel.
dataset.context: Rule 35(g): A vessel at anchor may in addition sound three blasts in succession, namely one short, one prolonged and one short blast, to give warning of her position and of the possibility of collision to an approaching vessel.

dataset.question: What sound signals does a vessel aground make?
dataset.answer: A vessel aground shall give the bell signal and if required the gong signal as for anchored vessels and shall, in addition, give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell immediately before and after the rapid ringing. She may in addition sound an appropriate whistle signal.
dataset.context: Rule 35(h): A vessel aground shall give the bell signal and if required the gone signal prescribed in paragraph (g) of this Rule and shall, in addition, give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell immediately before and after the rapid ringing of the bell. A vessel aground may in addition sound an appropriate whistle signal.

dataset.question: What sound signals must vessels 12-20 meters make in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: A vessel of 12 metres or more but less than 20 metres in length shall not be obliged to give the bell signals prescribed for anchored and aground vessels. However, if she does not, she shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.
dataset.context: Rule 35(i): A vessel of 12 metres or more but less than 20 metres in length shall not be obliged to give the bell signals prescribed in paragraphs (g) and (h) of this Rule. However, if she does not, she shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.

dataset.question: What sound signals must vessels under 12 meters make in restricted visibility?
dataset.answer: A vessel of less than 12 metres in length shall not be obliged to give the above-mentioned signals but, if she does not, shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.
dataset.context: Rule 35(j): A vessel of less than 12 metres in length shall not be obliged to give the above-mentioned signals but, if she does not, shall make some other efficient sound signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.

dataset.question: What identity signal may a pilot vessel make?
dataset.answer: A pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty may in addition to other signals sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts.
dataset.context: Rule 35(k): A pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty may in addition to the signals prescribed in paragraphs (a), (b) or (g) of this Rule sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts.

dataset.question: What signals may vessels use to attract attention?
dataset.answer: If necessary to attract the attention of another vessel any vessel may make light or sound signals that cannot be mistaken for any signal authorized elsewhere in these Rules, or may direct the beam of her searchlight in the direction of the danger, in such a way as not to embarrass any vessel.
dataset.context: Rule 36: If necessary to attract the attention of another vessel any vessel may make light or sound signals that cannot be mistaken for any signal authorized elsewhere in these Rules, or may direct the beam of her searchlight in the direction of the danger, in such a way as not to embarrass any vessel.

dataset.question: Should strobe lights be used to attract attention?
dataset.answer: For the purpose of attracting attention, the use of high intensity intermittent or revolving lights, such as strobe lights, shall be avoided.
dataset.context: Rule 36: For the purpose of this Rule the use of high intensity intermittent or revolving lights, such as strove lights, shall be avoided.

dataset.question: Where are distress signals described?
dataset.answer: When a vessel is in distress and requires assistance she shall use or exhibit the signals described in Annex IV to these Regulations.
dataset.context: Rule 37: When a vessel is in distress and requires assistance she shall use or exhibit the signals described in Annex IV to these Regulations.

dataset.question: What is the exemption for repositioning lights due to metric conversion?
dataset.answer: The repositioning of lights as a result of conversion from Imperial to metric units and rounding off measurement figures receives permanent exemption.
dataset.context: Rule 38(c): The repositioning of lights as a result of conversion from Imperial to metric units and rounding off measurement figures, permanent exemption.

dataset.question: What is the exemption period for repositioning masthead lights?
dataset.answer: For vessels under 150 meters, permanent exemption. For vessels 150 meters or more, exemption until nine years after entry into force.
dataset.context: Rule 38(d): The repositioning of masthead lights on vessels of less than 150 meters in length, resulting from the prescriptions of Section 3(a) of Annex I, permanent exemption. The repositioning of masthead lights on vessels of 150 meters or more in length, until nine years after the date of entry into force.

dataset.question: What does 'audit' mean in Rule 39?
dataset.answer: Audit means a systematic, independent and documented process for obtaining audit evidence and evaluating it objectively to determine the extent to which audit criteria are fulfilled.
dataset.context: Rule 39(a): Audit means a systematic, independent and documented process for obtaining audit evidence and evaluating it objectively to determine the extent to which audit criteria are fulfilled.

dataset.question: What is the Audit Scheme referred to in Rule 39?
dataset.answer: The Audit Scheme means the IMO Member State Audit Scheme established by the Organization and taking into account the guidelines developed by the Organization.
dataset.context: Rule 39(b): Audit Scheme means the IMO Member State Audit Scheme established by the Organization and taking into account the guidelines developed by the Organization.

dataset.question: What is the Code for Implementation?
dataset.answer: The Code for Implementation means the IMO Instruments Implementation Code (III Code) adopted by the Organization by resolution A.1070(28).
dataset.context: Rule 39(c): Code for Implementation means the IMO Instruments Implementation Code (III Code) adopted by the Organization by resolution A.1070(28).

dataset.question: How must Contracting Parties execute their obligations under COLREG?
dataset.answer: Contracting Parties shall use the provisions of the Code for Implementation in the execution of their obligations and responsibilities contained in the present Convention.
dataset.context: Rule 40: Contracting Parties shall use the provisions of the Code for Implementation in the execution of their obligations and responsibilities contained in the present Convention.

dataset.question: Must Contracting Parties undergo audits?
dataset.answer: Every Contracting Party shall be subject to periodic audits by the Organization in accordance with the audit standard to verify compliance with and implementation of the present Convention.
dataset.context: Rule 41(a): Every Contracting Party shall be subject to periodic audits by the Organization in accordance with the audit standard to verify compliance with and implementation of the present Convention.

dataset.question: Who administers the COLREG Audit Scheme?
dataset.answer: The Secretary-General of the Organization shall have responsibility for administering the Audit Scheme.
dataset.context: Rule 41(b): The Secretary-General of the Organization shall have responsibility for administering the Audit Scheme, based on the guidelines developed by the Organization.

dataset.question: What is a Contracting Party's responsibility regarding audits?
dataset.answer: Every Contracting Party shall have responsibility for facilitating the conduct of the audit and implementation of a programme of actions to address the findings.
dataset.context: Rule 41(c): Every Contracting Party shall have responsibility for facilitating the conduct of the audit and implementation of a programme of actions to address the findings, based on the guidelines developed by the Organization.

dataset.question: What does 'height above the hull' mean in Annex I?
dataset.answer: The term 'height above the hull' means height above the uppermost continuous deck. This height shall be measured from the position vertically beneath the location of the light.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 1: The term 'height above the hull' means height above the uppermost continuous deck. This height shall be measured from the position vertically beneath the location of the light.

dataset.question: What is the minimum height for the forward masthead light on vessels 20 meters or more?
dataset.answer: At a height above the hull of not less than 6 meters, and, if the breadth of the vessel exceeds 6 meters, then at a height above the hull not less than such breadth, so however that the light need not be placed at a greater height above the hull than 12 metres.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 2(a)(i): the forward masthead light, or if only one masthead light is carried, then that light, at a height above the hull of not less than 6 meters, and, if the breadth of the vessel exceeds 6 meters, then at a height above the hull not less than such breadth, so however that the light need not be placed at a greater height above the hull than 12 metres.

dataset.question: What is the minimum vertical separation between two masthead lights?
dataset.answer: When two masthead lights are carried the after one shall be at least 4.5 metres vertically higher than the forward one.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 2(a)(ii): when two masthead lights are carried the after one shall be at least 4.5 metres vertically higher than the forward one.

dataset.question: At what distance should the after masthead light be visible over the forward one?
dataset.answer: The vertical separation shall be such that in all normal conditions of trim the after light will be seen over and separate from the forward light at a distance of 1,000 meters from the stem when viewed from sea level.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 2(b): The vertical separation of mastheadlights of power-driven vessels shall be such that in all normal conditions of trim the after light will be seen over and separate from the forward light at a distance of 1,000 meters from the stem when viewed from sea level.

dataset.question: What is the minimum height for masthead lights on vessels 12-20 meters?
dataset.answer: The masthead light shall be placed at a height above the gunwale of not less than 2.5 metres.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 2(c): The masthead light of a power-driven vessel of 12 metres but less than 20 metres in length shall be placed at a height above the gunwale of not less than 2.5 metres.

dataset.question: At what height should sidelights not be greater than?
dataset.answer: The sidelights of a power-driven vessel shall be placed at a height above the hull not greater than three quarters of that of the forward masthead light.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 2(g): The sidelights of a power-driven vessel shall be placed at a height above the hull not greater than three quarters of that of the forward masthead light.

dataset.question: What is the minimum spacing for vertical lights on vessels 20 meters or more?
dataset.answer: On a vessel of 20 metres in length or more such lights shall be spaced not less than 2 metres apart, and the lowest shall, except where a towing light is required, be placed at a height of not less than 4 m above the hull.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 2(i)(i): on a vessel of 20 metres in length or more such lights shall be spaced not less than 2 metres apart, and the lowest of these lights shall, except where a towing light is required, be placed at a height of not less than 4 m above the hull.

dataset.question: What is the minimum horizontal distance between two masthead lights?
dataset.answer: When two masthead lights are prescribed, the horizontal distance between them shall not be less than one half of the length of the vessel but need not be more than 100 m.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 3(a): When two masthead lights are prescribed for a power-driven vessel, the horizontal distance between them shall not be less than one half of the length of the vessel but need not be more than 100 m.

dataset.question: What is the interpretation of 'near the side' for sidelight positioning?
dataset.answer: The term 'near the side' is interpreted as being a distance of not more than 10% of the breadth of the vessel inboard from the side, up to a maximum of 1 metre.
dataset.context: MSC.1/Circ.1260 - Annex I, section 3(b): The term 'near the side' is interpreted as being a distance of not more than 10% of the breadth of the vessel inboard from the side, up to a maximum of 1 metre.

dataset.question: What are the screens requirements for sidelights on vessels 20 meters or more?
dataset.answer: The sidelights of vessels of 20 metres or more in length shall be fitted with inboard screens painted matt black to meet the requirements of Annex I, Section 9.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 5: The sidelights of vessels of 20 metres or more in length shall be fitted with inboard screens painted matt black, and meeting the requirements of Section 9 of this Annex.

dataset.question: What is the minimum diameter for a cone day shape?
dataset.answer: A cone shall have a base diameter of not less than 0.6 metre and a height equal to its diameter.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 6(a)(ii): a cone shall have a base diameter of not less than 0.6 metre and a height equal to its diameter.

dataset.question: What is the formula for calculating minimum luminous intensity of lights?
dataset.answer: I = 3.43  10^6  T  D^2  K^-1 where I is luminous intensity in candelas, T is threshold factor 210^-7 lux, D is range of visibility in nautical miles, and K is atmospheric transmissivity (0.8 for prescribed lights).
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 8(a): I = 3.43  10^6  T  D^2  K^-1

dataset.question: What is the luminous intensity required for a light visible at 6 miles?
dataset.answer: For a light with range of visibility of 6 nautical miles, the luminous intensity should be 94 candelas for K = 0.8.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 8(b) Table: Range of visibility 6 miles corresponds to luminous intensity 94 candelas for K = 0.8.

dataset.question: What are the horizontal sector requirements for sidelights?
dataset.answer: In the forward direction, sidelights must show minimum required intensities, decreasing to practical cut-off between 1 and 3 degrees outside the prescribed 112.5 sectors.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 9(a)(i): In the forward direction, sidelights as fitted on the vessel shall show the minimum required intensities. The intensities must decrease to reach practical cut-off between 1 degree and 3 degrees outside the prescribed sectors.

dataset.question: What are the vertical sector requirements for electric lights?
dataset.answer: Electric lights (except on sailing vessels) must maintain at least the required minimum intensity from 5 above to 5 below horizontal, and at least 60% from 7.5 above to 7.5 below horizontal.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 10(a): The vertical sectors of electric lights as fitted, with the exception of lights on sailing vessels underway shall ensure that: (i) at least the required minimum intensity is maintained at all angles from 5 degrees above to 5 degrees below the horizontal; (ii) at least 60 per cent of the required minimum intensity is maintained from 7.5 degrees above to 7.5 degrees below the horizontal.

dataset.question: Where should the manoeuvring light be positioned?
dataset.answer: The manoeuvring light shall be placed in the same fore and aft vertical plane as masthead lights, at least 2 metres vertically above the forward masthead light, and not less than 2 metres vertically above or below the after masthead light.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 12: The manoeuvring light shall be placed in the same fore and aft vertical plane as the masthead light or lights and, where practicable, at a minimum height of 2 metres vertically above the forward masthead light, provided that it shall be carried not less than 2 meters vertically above or below the after masthead light.

dataset.question: What are the additional signals for trawlers shooting their nets?
dataset.answer: Vessels of 20m or more engaged in trawling when shooting their nets shall exhibit two white lights in a vertical line.
dataset.context: Annex II, Section 2(a)(i): when shooting their nets: two white lights in a vertical line.

dataset.question: What signals do purse seiners exhibit when hampered?
dataset.answer: Vessels engaged in fishing with purse seine gear may exhibit two yellow lights in a vertical line that flash alternately every second, only when hampered by fishing gear.
dataset.context: Annex II, Section 3: Vessels engaged in fishing with purse seine gear may exhibit two yellow lights in a vertical line. These lights shall flash alternately every second and with equal light and occultation duration. These lights may be exhibited only when the vessel is hampered by its fishing gear.

dataset.question: What is the frequency range for whistles on vessels of 20m or more?
dataset.answer: For vessels of 20 metres or more in length, the fundamental frequency of the whistle shall lie within the range 70-700Hz, and the audibility range determined by frequencies 180-700Hz (1%).
dataset.context: Annex III, Section 1(a): The fundamental frequency of the signal shall lie within the range 70-700Hz. The range of audibility of the signal from a whistle shall be determined by those frequencies which lie within the range 180-700Hz (+/-1%) for a vessel of 20 metres or more in length.

dataset.question: What is the minimum sound pressure level for a whistle on a 200m vessel?
dataset.answer: For a vessel of 200m or more, the whistle must provide a sound pressure level of at least 143 dB at 1 metre in the appropriate 1/3-octave band.
dataset.context: Annex III, Section 1(c) Table: Length of vessel 200 or more  1/3rd-octave band level at 1 metre: 143 dB.

dataset.question: What is the minimum diameter for a bell on vessels 20m or more?
dataset.answer: The diameter of the mouth of the bell shall be not less than 300 mm for vessels of 20 metres or more in length.
dataset.context: Annex III, Section 2(b): The diameter of the mouth of the bell shall be not less than 300 mm for vessels of 20 metres or more in length.

dataset.question: What are the distress signals listed in Annex IV?
dataset.answer: Distress signals include: gun or explosive signals fired at intervals; continuous fog signal; red star rockets; SOS signal; MAYDAY; N.C. flag; square flag with ball; flames; red flares; orange smoke; raising/lowering arms; EPIRB signals.
dataset.context: Annex IV, Section 1: Lists multiple distress signals including those described in (a) through (o).

dataset.question: What is the master's responsibility regarding watchkeeping arrangements?
dataset.answer: The master of every ship is bound to ensure that watchkeeping arrangements are adequate for maintaining a safe navigational watch.
dataset.context: IMO Recommendation on Navigational Watchkeeping, Section 1, para 1: The master of every ship is bound to ensure that the watchkeeping arrangements are adequate for maintaining a safe navigational watch.

dataset.question: When can the officer of the watch be the sole look-out?
dataset.answer: The officer of the watch may be the sole look-out in daylight only after careful assessment and when established without doubt that it is safe, considering factors like weather, visibility, traffic density, and proximity of hazards.
dataset.context: IMO Recommendation, Section I, para 11(c): There may be circumstances in which the officer of the watch can safely be the sole look-out in daylight. However, this practice shall only be followed after the situation has been carefully assessed...

dataset.question: What should the officer of the watch do when taking over the watch?
dataset.answer: The relieving officer should ensure vision is adjusted to light conditions and personally satisfy himself regarding: standing orders; position, course, speed, draught; tides, currents, weather, visibility; and navigational situation including equipment condition and traffic.
dataset.context: IMO Recommendation, Section II, para 9: The relieving officer should not take over the watch until his vision is fully adjusted to the light conditions and he has personally satisfied himself regarding: (a) standing orders... (b) the position, course, speed and draught... (c) prevailing and predicted tides... (d) the navigational situation...

dataset.question: When should the officer of the watch notify the master?
dataset.answer: The officer should notify the master immediately when: restricted visibility encountered; traffic conditions cause concern; difficulty maintaining course; failure to sight land/navigation mark; unexpected sighting of land/mark; breakdown of essential equipment; heavy weather concerns; any emergency or doubt.
dataset.context: IMO Recommendation, Section II, para 25: The officer of the watch should notify the master immediately under circumstances: (a) if restricted visibility is encountered... (b) if the traffic conditions... (c) if difficulty is experienced... (d) on failure to sight land... (e) if land or a navigation mark is sighted... (f) on the breakdown... (g) in heavy weather... (h) in any other emergency...

dataset.question: What are the watchkeeping duties for a vessel at anchor?
dataset.answer: The officer should: determine and plot ship's position; ensure efficient look-out; make inspection rounds; observe meteorological/tidal conditions; notify master if dragging anchor; ensure main engines readiness; notify master if visibility deteriorates; exhibit appropriate lights/shapes; take anti-pollution measures.
dataset.context: IMO Recommendation, Section II, para 28: The officer of the watch should: (a) determine and plot the ship's position... (b) ensure that and efficient look-out is maintained; (c) ensure that inspection rounds... (d) observe meteorological and tidal conditions... (e) notify the master if dragging anchor... (f) ensure that the state of readiness... (g) if visibility deteriorates... (h) ensure that the vessel exhibits... (i) take measures to protect the environment...

dataset.question: What does 'Article I: General Obligations' require of Parties to COLREG?
dataset.answer: The Parties undertake to give effect to the Rules and other Annexes constituting the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea, 1972.
dataset.context: Article I: The Parties to the present Convention undertake to give effect to the Rules and other Annexes constituting the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea, 1972.

dataset.question: When did COLREG 1972 enter into force according to Article IV?
dataset.answer: The Convention entered into force twelve months after at least 15 States with merchant fleets constituting not less than 65% of world tonnage became Parties, but not before 1 January 1976.
dataset.context: Article IV(1): (a) The present Convention shall enter into force twelve months after the date on which at least 15 States, the aggregate of whose merchant fleets constitutes not less than 65 per cent... have become Parties to it... (b) Notwithstanding... the present Convention shall not enter into force before 1 January 1976.

dataset.question: What does Article II specify about signature and accession to COLREG?
dataset.answer: Article II states that the Convention remained open for signature until 1 June 1973 and thereafter remains open for accession by UN Member States, specialized agency members, IAEA members, or ICJ Statute parties.
dataset.context: Article II(1): The present Convention shall remain open for signature until 1 June 1973 and shall thereafter remain open for accession.

dataset.question: How can States become Parties to COLREG according to Article II?
dataset.answer: States may become Parties by: (a) signature without reservation as to ratification; (b) signature subject to ratification followed by ratification; or (c) accession.
dataset.context: Article II(2): States may become Parties to this Convention by: (a) signature without reservation, as to ratification, acceptance or approval; (b) signature subject to ratification, acceptance or approval followed by ratification, acceptance or approval; or (c) accession.

dataset.question: What does Article III allow regarding territorial application of COLREG?
dataset.answer: Article III allows the UN or any Contracting Party responsible for international relations of a territory to extend the Convention's application to such territory by written notification to the Secretary-General.
dataset.context: Article III(1): The United Nations... or any Contracting Party responsible for the international relations of a territory, may at any time by notification in writing to the Secretary-General... extend the application of this Convention to such a territory.

dataset.question: How does Article V provide for revision of COLREG?
dataset.answer: Article V states that a Conference for revising the Convention or Regulations may be convened by IMO, and IMO shall convene a Conference at the request of not less than one-third of Contracting Parties.
dataset.context: Article V(1): A Conference for the purpose of revising this Convention or the Regulations or both may be convened by the Organization. (2) The Organization shall convene a Conference... at the request of not less than one-third of the Contracting Parties.

dataset.question: What is the procedure for denouncing COLREG under Article VII?
dataset.answer: A Contracting Party may denounce the Convention after 5 years from its entry into force for that Party, by depositing an instrument with IMO, with denunciation taking effect one year or longer period after deposit.
dataset.context: Article VII(1): The present Convention may be denounced by a Contracting Party at any time after the expiry of five years from the date on which the Convention entered into force for that Party.

dataset.question: What does Article VIII specify about deposit and registration of COLREG?
dataset.answer: Article VIII requires the Convention and Regulations to be deposited with IMO, with certified true copies transmitted to all signatory/accession governments, and text transmitted to UN Secretariat for registration upon entry into force.
dataset.context: Article VIII(1): The present Convention and the Regulations shall be deposited with the Organization... (2) When the present Convention enters into force, the text shall be transmitted by the Secretary-General to the Secretariat of the United Nations for registration...

dataset.question: What are the authentic languages of COLREG according to Article IX?
dataset.answer: COLREG is established in a single copy in English and French, both texts equally authentic, with official translations in Russian and Spanish prepared and deposited with the signed original.
dataset.context: Article IX: The present Convention is established, together with the Regulations, in a single copy in the English and French languages, both texts being equally authentic. Official translations in the Russian and Spanish languages shall be prepared...

dataset.question: What exemption does Rule 38 provide for vessels complying with 1960 Regulations?
dataset.answer: Rule 38 allows vessels that comply with the 1960 Regulations and whose keel was laid before COLREG 1972 entry into force to be exempted from certain requirements as specified in paragraphs (a) to (h).
dataset.context: Rule 38: Any vessel (or class of vessels) provided that she complies with the requirements of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea, 1960, the keel of which is laid... before the entry into force of these Regulations may be exempted...

dataset.question: What does Rule 1(e) allow for vessels of special construction?
dataset.answer: Rule 1(e) allows governments to determine alternative provisions for vessels of special construction that cannot fully comply with COLREG requirements for lights, shapes, or sound-signalling appliances, provided these are the closest possible compliance.
dataset.context: Rule 1(e): Whenever the Government concerned shall have determined that a vessel of special construction or purpose cannot comply fully with the provisions... such vessel shall comply with such other provisions... as her Government shall have determined to be the closest possible compliance...

dataset.question: What is the minimum horizontal distance required for lights indicating direction of outlying fishing gear?
dataset.answer: The light indicating direction of outlying gear must be placed at a horizontal distance of not less than 2 metres and not more than 6 metres away from the two all-round red and white lights.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 4(a): The light indicating the direction of the outlying gear... shall be placed at a horizontal distance of not less than 2 metres and not more than 6 metres away from the two all-round red and white lights.

dataset.question: What are the placement requirements for lights on dredging vessels indicating obstruction?
dataset.answer: Lights indicating obstruction on dredging vessels must be placed at the maximum practical horizontal distance, but not less than 2 metres, from the lights/shapes prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and (ii).
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 4(b): The lights and shapes on a vessel engaged in dredging... to indicate the obstructed side... shall be placed at the maximum practical horizontal distance, but in no case less than 2 metres, from the lights or shapes prescribed in Rule 27(b)(i) and (ii).

dataset.question: What are the dimensions for a cylinder day shape?
dataset.answer: A cylinder shall have a diameter of at least 0.6 metre and a height of twice its diameter.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 6(a)(iii): a cylinder shall have a diameter of at least 0.6 metre and a height of twice its diameter.

dataset.question: What is the minimum vertical distance between shapes?
dataset.answer: The vertical distance between shapes shall be at least 1.5 metres.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 6(b): The vertical distance between shapes shall be at least 1.5 metres.

dataset.question: What allowance exists for shapes on vessels less than 20 metres?
dataset.answer: On vessels less than 20 metres in length, shapes of lesser dimensions commensurate with vessel size may be used, and the distance apart may be correspondingly reduced.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 6(c): In a vessel of less than 20 metres in length shapes of lesser dimensions but commensurate with the size of the vessel may be used and the distance apart may be correspondingly reduced.

dataset.question: What are the CIE chromaticity coordinates for yellow navigation lights?
dataset.answer: Yellow navigation lights must conform to coordinates: x 0.612, 0.618, 0.575, 0.575 and y 0.382, 0.382, 0.425, 0.406.

dataset.question: What atmospheric transmissivity (K) value is used for prescribed lights?
dataset.answer: For prescribed lights, the value of K (atmospheric transmissivity) shall be 0.8, corresponding to a meteorological visibility of approximately 13 nautical miles.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 8(a): For prescribed lights the value of K shall be 0.8, corresponding to a meteorological visibility of approximately 13 nautical miles.

dataset.question: What is the note regarding maximum luminous intensity of navigation lights?
dataset.answer: The maximum luminous intensity of navigation lights should be limited to avoid undue glare, and this shall not be achieved by variable control of luminous intensity.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 8(b) NOTE: The maximum luminous intensity of navigation lights should be limited to avoid undue glare. This shall not be achieved by a variable control of the luminous intensity.

dataset.question: What is required for all-round lights regarding obscuration by structures?
dataset.answer: All-round lights shall be so located as not to be obscured by masts, topmasts or structures within angular sectors of more than 6 degrees.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 9(b)(i): All-round lights shall be so located as not to be obscured by masts, topmasts or structures within angular sectors of more than 6 degrees...

dataset.question: What is the exception for anchor lights regarding placement height?
dataset.answer: Anchor lights prescribed in Rule 30 need not be placed at an impracticable height above the hull.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 9(b)(i): ...except anchor lights prescribed in Rule 30, which need not be placed at an impracticable height above the hull.

dataset.question: What alternative is allowed if single all-round light compliance is impracticable?
dataset.answer: If impracticable to exhibit only one all-round light, two all-round lights may be used suitably positioned or screened to appear as one light at 1 mile.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 9(b)(ii): If it is impracticable to comply with paragraph (b)(i) of this section by exhibiting only one all-round light, two all-round lights shall be used suitably positioned or screened so that they appear, as far as practicable, as one light at a distance of one mile.

dataset.question: What formula determines screening of all-round lights according to MSC.1/Circ.1260/Rev.1?
dataset.answer: 2  360 - 1, where 1 is screened angle of one all-round light and 2 is screened angle of the other all-round light.
dataset.context: MSC.1/Circ.1260/Rev.1, Annex I, section 9(b): 2  360 - 1 where 1 : Screened angle of one all-round light; 2 : Screened angle of the other all-round light.

dataset.question: What are vertical sector requirements for sailing vessels underway?
dataset.answer: For sailing vessels underway, electric lights must maintain at least required minimum intensity from 5 above to 5 below horizontal, and at least 50% from 25 above to 25 below horizontal.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 10(b): In the case of sailing vessels underway the vertical sectors of electric lights as fitted shall ensure that: (i) at least the required minimum intensity is maintained at all angles from 5 degrees above to 5 degrees below the horizontal; (ii) at least 50 per cent of the required minimum intensity is maintained from 25 degrees above to 25 degrees below the horizontal.

dataset.question: What specification applies to non-electric lights?
dataset.answer: Non-electric lights shall so far as practicable comply with the minimum intensities specified in the Table in Section 8 of Annex I.
dataset.context: Annex I, Section 11: Non-electric lights shall so far as practicable comply with the minimum intensities, as specified in the Table given in Section 8 of this Annex.
